Name: LINOLEIC ACID
Description: Linoleic acid is an octadecadienoic acid in which the two double bonds are at positions 9 and 12 and have Z (cis) stereochemistry. It has a role as a plant metabolite, a Daphnia galeata metabolite and an algal metabolite. It is an omega-6 fatty acid and an octadecadienoic acid. It is a conjugate acid of a linoleate.

plant_concentrations.References: (1) Rogge WF et al; Environ Sci Technol 27: 2700-11 (1993) (2) Johnson RW, Daniels RW; Carboxylic Acids, Manufacure. Kirk-Othmer Encyclopedia of Chemical Technology. (1999-2014). New York, NY: John Wiley & Sons. Online Posting Date: Dec 4, 2000
plant_concentrations.Value: Linoleic acid was found in fine particulate matter released (by resuspension and agitation of the leaf composites) from green and dead plant leaves, from plant species characteristic of the Los Angeles area, at concentrations of 110.8 and 71.8 ug/g, respectively(1). Linoleic acid is found in cotton oil (33-58 wt%); coconut oil (1-3 wt%); palm kernel oil (1-3 wt%); corn oil (34-62 wt%); palm oil (9-12 wt%); castor oil (2-7 wt%); rapeseed oil, low erucic (18-30 wt%); rapeseed oil, high erucic (11-25 wt%); soybean oil (48-58 wt%); and sunflower oil (50-70 wt%)(2).

plant_concentrations.References: (1) USDA; Dr. Duke's Phytochemical and Ethnobotanical Databases. Plants with a chosen chemical. Linoleic acid. Washington, DC: US Dept Agric, Agric Res Service. Available from, as of Jan 17, 2014: https://www.ars-grin.gov/duke/

fish_seafood_concentrations.References: (1) Owens JW et al; Chemosphere 29: 89-109 (1994) (2) Morales A et al; Water Environ Res 64: 660-8 (1992) (3) Hesselberg RJ, Seelye JG; Identification of Organic Compounds in Great Lakes Fishes by Gas Chromatography/Mass Spectrometry, Admen Rep No 82-1, Ann Arbor, MI: US Fish Wildlife Soc Great Lakes Fishery Lab (1982) (4) Avery EL et al; Arch Environ Contam Toxicol 35: 229-35 (1998) (5) Johnson RW, Daniels RW; Carboxylic Acids, Manufacure. Kirk-Othmer Encyclopedia of Chemical Technology. (1999-2014). New York, NY: John Wiley & Sons. Online Posting Date: Dec 4, 2000. (6) Hamilton MC et al; Environ Sci Technol 39: 8622-8629 (2005)
fish_seafood_concentrations.Value: Bile samples from mountain whitefish (Prosopium williamsoni) and longnose sucker (Catostomus catostomus), contained linoleic acid at concentrations ranging from 7.6 to 23.0 ppm, for fish captured immediately below a bleached kraft pulp mill in Alberta, Canada; 0 to 73.0 ppm, for fish captured 15 to 30 km downstream of the mill; and 19.0 to 31.0 ppm, for fish captured 230 km downstream of the mill(1). Linoleic acid was detected in bile samples of fish collected in the northern Alberta region of Canada during the summer and fall of 1990, at concentrations ranging from <1 ug/g to 520 ug/g(2). Linoleic acid was identified in extracts from Great Lakes trout and walleye taken from Lake Erie (Dunkirk)(3). Linoleic acid was detected in Sydney rock oysters (Saccostrea commercialis) deployed in mesh bags in the Redhead and Hunter regions of New South Wales, Australia; linoleic acid was detected in 0.436% lipid material in 83 control samples from the Redhead region which is not directly exposed to sources of sewage pollution(4). The compound was detected in 0.546% lipid material of 59 samples taken in the Hunter region, an area of extended sewage outfall(4). Linoleic acid is found in herring oil (2-4% wt%) and sardine oil (3-8% wt%)(5). The average lipid content of linoleic acid from 45 wild salmon, 153 farmed salmon and 48 supermarket salmon was found to be 0.67, 6.47 and 6.04 mg/g wet weight, respectively(6).

sediment_soil_concentrations.References: (1) Morales A et al; Water Environ Res 64: 660-8 (1992)
sediment_soil_concentrations.Value: SEDIMENT: Sediment samples collected from the northern Alberta region of Canada during the summer and fall of 1990, contained linoleic acid at concentrations ranging from <0.05 to 0.5 ug/g(1).
